Not all banks that are short on funds get emergency liquidity assistance. There are strict rules in place to prevent banks from deciding to take greater risks based on the knowledge that there will always be a lender of last resort to back them up 4/4 https://t.co/SZCZM9L6zo

The ECB and the 19 national central banks in the euro area share the role of lender of last resort. Their main tool is emergency liquidity assistance, which is the last safety net for banks 3/4 https://t.co/Oj55fyj67C

The lender of last resort does not just have the fate of a single bank in mind but also the well-being of the economy: without funding, banks can’t lend to businesses or people. The consequences of a bank failure could be far-reaching and even affect jobs and savings 2/4

The ECB has set up an internal dataset, based on publicly available data, to analyse crypto-assets. Initiatives by the ECB and the central banking community are expected to help close any data gaps that currently exist https://t.co/jkk9FGebqP 4/4

What risks do crypto-assets entail? They lack fundamental value, making them subject to speculation and volatility, while their holders aren’t legally protected. It isn’t easy to determine who should identify, mitigate and manage the significant risks posed by crypto-assets. 3/4 https://t.co/9bdRvwpp6Y

We are analysing the crypto-asset phenomenon to understand its risks and enhance monitoring efforts. But what exactly are crypto-assets? An Occasional Paper published on our website in May provides a useful definition. 2/4 https://t.co/DF5hAk2CTM

(THREAD) What characterises crypto-assets such as #bitcoin? What risks do they pose to the financial system? And how can publicly available data help the ECB monitor this phenomenon? Read on and see our article for more detail https://t.co/MpeEXvCsii 1/4 https://t.co/snHOZ0CfAg

Despite some signs of recovery, global trade is likely to remain more subdued than economic activity in coming quarters while the threat of a further escalation of trade tensions persists. Want to find out more? Read the full article here https://t.co/UP4Jah2zRO 4/4 https://t.co/WoQYzOhYfu

The sharp decline in global manufacturing output – which is particularly evident in the electronics and automotive sectors – has resulted in world trade declining more strongly than global GDP, as the manufacturing sector remains highly trade-intensive. 3/4 https://t.co/pcCkPqDKSt

The drop in global trade reflects weak investment and declining manufacturing output. Rising global uncertainty and tighter financing conditions largely explain the investment slowdown seen in both advanced economies and emerging market economies in the second half of 2018. 2/4 https://t.co/7PS4b4Vr8v

(THREAD) Both global GDP growth and world trade have declined since mid-2018. However, trade has slowed particularly sharply and contracted at the start of 2019. What caused this sharp slowdown? Read on or see the full Economic Bulletin article here  https://t.co/mtEP8HQFED 1/4 https://t.co/CVJyvukM0n
